awd_titl_txt: Conference: Planning and Development of a Nearshore Extreme Event Reconnaissance (NEER); Arlington, Virginia; August 5-6, 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant funds a conference to be held August 5-6, 2019 in Arlington, Virginia, titled Planning and Development of a Nearshore Extreme Event Reconnaissance (NEER). The objective of the conference is to bring together experienced members of the extreme event community, and a broad group of scientists to develop a coordinated effort to address key hypotheses, to support pre- and post-storm site characterization and collection of socio-economic data, to plan for deployment of instruments to record during-storm measurements, to consider interactions and feedbacks between the natural and built environments and human actions and reactions, and to enable safe, pre- and post-storm activities. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be insights to improve resilience of coastal communities, which will save lives and economic losses. 

The framework for a coordinated response to extreme coastal storms that is developed during this conference will enable collection of perishable data needed to understand storm impacts on the natural and built environments and human residents which ultimately will lead to more resilient coastal communities. During the conference, participants will meet in groups of 5 to 8 where smaller groups will focus on: 1) organizational structure, 2) protocols, 3) issues for pre-event deployments, and 4) integration and coordination. This conference connects researchers from several disciplines who study the impacts of hazardous storms enabling convergence of research methods and ideas within the fields of engineering, geosciences, biology, and socio-economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to hold a conference to develop the framework for a Nearshore Extreme Event Reconnaissance (NEER) association that could coordinate interdisciplinary, rapid-deployment studies to obtain perishable observations of coastal storm impacts on the natural and built environments in the nearshore water-land system, and the human responses to these hazards.

 A conference was held on Aug 5-6, 2019 that brought together scientists spanning a wide range of fields who were interested in coordinated rapid response efforts needed to understand interactions and feedbacks between processes during extreme events. The participants included geoscientists (oceanographers, geomorphologists, biogeochemists), ecologists, biologists, engineers (structural, coastal, and geotechnical), and socio-economic scientists. In addition, the SHORELINE21 conference included a session for emerging members. The NEER Association currently has more than 125 members across the United States.

NEER supported several event responses from 2020 to 2023 that included student and emerging members. All the students members who participated in NEER responses plan to remain involved in natural hazards work, and to remain as academic or partner members of NEER. However, they also expressed interest in a hands-on in person meeting to discuss logistics and support mechanisms for participants new to natural hazards research. Thus, a NEER meeting focused on emerging members was held in concert with the Coastal Sediments meeting in New Orleans LA (April 2023). NEER organized 3 sessions around the theme "Interdisciplinary Investigations into Water-Land Processes During Major Storms.” Members shared results of rapid response efforts associated with coastal storms on a variety of US coasts (including arctic, island, and mainland regions), novel techniques for measuring storm impacts, interactions and information exchange efforts with impacted communities, and methods to assess coastal defenses and resilience. A total of 18 oral and 4 poster presentations were given during the sessions, resulting in stimulating discussions and questions among the coastal engineers, oceanographers, geomorphologists, geotechnical engineers, hydrogeologists, ecologists, and sociologists who attended. A lunchtime meeting enabled interactions and discussions among 50 participants, including 28 students and postdocs, as well as emerging natural disaster researchers and active experienced NEER members. Following an introduction to NEER’s vision and mission, the participants discussed their goals for disaster research, and how they could work together across disciplines to understand coastal storm impacts. The input from this meeting is being used to extend and adapt the NEER Association (https://neerassociation.org).
